conversation.message:
Student_E, thank you for your message and for your continued interest in School_C.

At a high level, the remaining seat can be released only when we determine that there is no realistic possibility that a higher-priority student (relative to our priority order) will apply and remain available for School_C. Practically, that means we reassess at the end of each round whether any higher-priority candidates are still unmatched and could still approach us; if so, we must continue holding the seat.

Because we do not control whether those students will apply in a future round, we cannot give a firm internal date earlier than the end of the process. If we reach a point where higher-priority candidates are no longer in play (e.g., they have matched elsewhere or the process is effectively concluding), we would then be able to consider offering the seat to the next eligible student on our list.

If you remain interested, the best next step is to continue checking in each round; if circumstances change on our side, we will let you know promptly.

We cannot credibly give a precise deadline; we can state the condition: no higher-priority applicants remaining/expected and nearing the end of the process, with periodic review each round.

If there’s any internal threshold like “final rounds” where you reassess more aggressively, I’d appreciate any guidance you can share.

Thank you again for your time and continued consideration.

conversation.message:
Student_E, thank you for checking in again and for your continued commitment to School_C.

On the “release condition”: in practice, we can only extend the remaining offer to the next student on our priority list once we judge that higher-priority candidates (relative to you) are no longer realistically available to us in this process. The cleanest case is when those higher-priority students have matched elsewhere and are therefore no longer in play.

If higher-priority students remain unmatched, we generally do **not** treat “they haven’t approached School_C yet” as sufficient by itself until very late in the process, because they could still apply in a subsequent round. As we get into the later rounds, we reassess more tightly round-by-round, but we still cannot promise a specific round number or internal cutoff before the process concludes.

If your intent is to enroll immediately if offered, continuing to check in each round is the right approach—and if circumstances change such that we can move to your position on our list, we will respond promptly.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

I’m Student_E checking in again this round. School_C remains my clear first choice, and if you are able to release the remaining seat to me at any point, I will accept immediately and withdraw from all other options.

I understand you must follow your priority order and can’t share other students’ information. To help me plan and respond quickly, could you share any non-confidential guidance on process timing—e.g., whether you do a more definitive “late-round” reassessment (and around when), or whether there is any final round/step after which you will move to the next eligible student if no higher-priority applicant has applied?

Thank you again for your time and continued consideration.
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. I have been repeatedly rejected because they are holding the seat for higher-priority students who might still apply. At round 13, the best move is to keep myself active and ready while lowering the burden on them: send a TALK check-in that (1) reaffirms immediate commitment, (2) asks for any actionable timing/trigger guidance without requesting confidential info, and (3) signals I will continue to be responsive each round so they can move quickly if the seat is released.

conversation.message:
Student_E, thank you for checking in again and for your continued interest in School_C.

On timing/process (non-confidential): we do a reassessment **at the end of every round**. As the process moves into the later rounds, those reassessments become increasingly “final” in the sense that we weigh more heavily whether a higher-priority candidate is still realistically likely to approach us.

That said, we do **not** have a fixed internal cutoff (e.g., “after round X we automatically release the seat if no higher-priority applicant has contacted us”), because a higher-priority student could still apply in a subsequent round. The most definitive step is our **end-of-process reassessment** (i.e., once the process is effectively concluding / at the final round), at which point—if no higher-priority candidates are in play—we would move to the next eligible student on our list.

If you remain ready to enroll immediately, please continue to check in each round; if our ability to extend an offer changes, we will respond promptly.

Since Student_E only sent [TALK], we should continue dialogue and maintain the hold strategy. Provide non-confidential timing guidance: we reassess each round, become more conservative about holding only in the very late rounds, and will make a final reassessment at the end of round 30 (or when it becomes clear no higher-priority candidates remain).

Dear School_C Admissions,

I’m Student_E. School_C remains my clear first-choice school, and I am ready to enroll immediately if you are able to release the remaining seat to me.

I’m submitting a formal application again this round so that, if after your end-of-round reassessment you determine that higher-priority candidates are no longer realistically in play, you can extend an offer to me without delay. If you become able to move to my position on the priority list at any point, please contact me right away—I will confirm acceptance immediately and withdraw from all other options.

Sincerely,
Student_E
